original: Udāna 2.6
analyzed: udāna
translated: The Collection of Long Discourses 1.1

original: Gabbhinīsutta
analyzed: gabbhinīsutta
translated: The Pregnant Woman

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa paribbājakassa daharamāṇavikā pajāpati hoti gabbhinī upavijaññā.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa paribbājakassa dahara māṇavikā pajāpati hoti gabbhinī upavijaññā
translated: Now on that occasion a certain wanderer had a young female wanderer as his wife, who was pregnant and near her confinement.

original: Atha kho sā paribbājikā taṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sā paribbājikā tam paribbājakam etat avoca
translated: Then the female wanderer said to the wanderer:

original: “gaccha tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, telaṁ āhara, yaṁ me vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: gaccha tva brāhmaṇa telam āhara yam me vijātāya bhavissati iti
translated: “Go, brahmin, and get some oil for when I give birth.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, so paribbājako taṁ paribbājikaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte saḥ paribbājakaḥ tam paribbājikam etat avoca
translated: When that was said, the wanderer replied:

original: “kuto panāhaṁ, bhoti, telaṁ āharāmī”ti?
analyzed: kutas pana āha bhoti telam āharāmi iti
translated: “But where, my dear, shall I get the oil?”

original: Dutiyampi kho sā paribbājikā taṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho sā paribbājikā tam paribbājakam etat avoca
translated: A second time she said to him:

original: “gaccha tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, telaṁ āhara, yaṁ me vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: gaccha tva brāhmaṇa telam āhara yam me vijātāya bhavissati iti
translated: “Go, brahmin, and get some oil for when I give birth.”

original: Dutiyampi kho so paribbājako taṁ paribbājikaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho saḥ paribbājakaḥ tam paribbājikam etat avoca
translated: A second time he replied:

original: “kuto panāhaṁ, bhoti, telaṁ āharāmī”ti?
analyzed: kutas pana āha bhoti telam āharāmi iti
translated: “But where, my dear, shall I get the oil?”

original: Tatiyampi kho sā paribbājikā taṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho sā paribbājikā tam paribbājakam etat avoca
translated: A third time, the female wanderer said to the male wanderer,

original: “gaccha tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, telaṁ āhara, yaṁ me vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: gaccha tva brāhmaṇa telam āhara yam me vijātāya bhavissati iti
translated: A third time, she said to him, “Go, brahmin, and get oil for what will happen when I give birth.”

original: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāre samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā yāvadatthaṁ pātuṁ dīyati, no nīharituṁ.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena raññaḥ pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāre samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā yāvadattham pātum dīyati no nīharitu
translated: “Now on that occasion, in the Kosalan King Pasenadi’s granary, oil was given to be drunk by contemplatives or brahmans, but not to be taken out.

original: Atha kho tassa paribbājakassa etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho tassa paribbājakassa etat ahosi
translated: Then the thought occurred to the wanderer,

original: “rañño kho pana pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāre samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā yāvadatthaṁ pātuṁ dīyati, no nīharituṁ.
analyzed: raññaḥ kho pana pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāre samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sappissa vā telassa vā yāvadattham pātum dīyati no nīharitu
translated: “In the Kosalan King Pasenadi’s granary, oil is given to be drunk by contemplatives or brahmans, but not to be taken out.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāraṁ gantvā telassa yāvadatthaṁ pivitvā gharaṁ āgantvā ucchadditvāna dadeyyaṁ, yaṁ imissā vijātāya bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāram gantvā telassa yāvadattham pivitvā gharam āgantvā dadeyya yam imissā vijātāya bhavissati iti
translated: “What if I were to go to the Kosalan King Pasenadi’s granary, drink as much oil as I want, come home, and throw up so that there will be for what will happen when she gives birth?”

original: Atha kho so paribbājako rañño pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāraṁ gantvā telassa yāvadatthaṁ pivitvā gharaṁ āgantvā neva sakkoti uddhaṁ kātuṁ, na pana adho.
analyzed: atha kho so paribbājakaḥ raññaḥ pasenadissa kosalassa koṭṭhāgāram gantvā telassa yāvadattham pivitvā gharam āgantvā na iva sakkoti uddham kātu na pana adhas
translated: The wanderer went to the Kosalan King Pasenadi’s granary and drank as much oil as he wanted. Then he returned home, but was unable to either defecate or urinate.

original: So dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭho āvaṭṭati parivaṭṭati.
analyzed: so dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭhaḥ āvaṭṭati parivaṭṭati
translated: He was overwhelmed by painful, sharp, severe, and bitter feelings. He rolled back and forth.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya sāvatthim piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: Then, in the morning, the Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Sāvatthī for alms.

original: Addasā kho bhagavā taṁ paribbājakaṁ dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭhaṁ āvaṭṭamānaṁ parivaṭṭamānaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho bhagavā tam paribbājakam dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭham āvaṭṭamānam parivaṭṭamāna
translated: He saw the wanderer overwhelmed by painful, sharp, severe, and bitter feelings, rolling back and forth.

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Knowing this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

original: “Sukhino vata ye akiñcanā,
analyzed: sukhinaḥ vata ye akiñcanā
translated: “Happy indeed are those who are free from possessions,

original: Vedaguno hi janā akiñcanā;
analyzed: vedagunaḥ hi janāḥ akiñcanā
translated: For the one who knows has no possessions.

original: Sakiñcanaṁ passa vihaññamānaṁ,
analyzed: sa kiñcanam passa vihaññamāna
translated: But look at the one with possessions, being tormented,

original: Jano janasmiṁ paṭibandhacitto”ti.
analyzed: janaḥ janasmim
translated: People are attached to other people.”

original: Chaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: chaṭṭha
translated: The sixth.
